title: Musical instrument
data:
- *This page is a **[stub](/wiki/Category:Stubs "Category:Stubs")**. Should you wish to do so, you can contribute by [**expanding this page**.](https://nethackwiki.com/index.php?title=Musical_instrument\&action=edit)*

**Musical instruments** are [tools](/wiki/Tool "Tool") that can be [applied](/wiki/Applied "Applied") to produce music, causing some sort of effect. Instruments in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* fall into two categories: *[tonal instruments](/wiki/Tonal_instrument "Tonal instrument")*, which can play tunes (including the [passtune](/wiki/Passtune "Passtune")), and *[atonal instruments](/wiki/Atonal_instrument "Atonal instrument")*, which cannot.

Some instruments are magical—they have effects beyond what their ordinary equivalent would yield. When they are uncharged, they behave identically to that equivalent. Every non-magical musical instrument except the [bugle](/wiki/Bugle "Bugle") has at least one magical counterpart. [Elven](/wiki/Elf_\(starting_race\) "Elf (starting race)") [Priests](/wiki/Priest "Priest") and [Wizards](/wiki/Wizard "Wizard") start with a non-magical musical instrument, excluding the tin whistle.

If you are [stunned](/wiki/Stun "Stun"), [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused"), or [hallucinating](/wiki/Hallucinating "Hallucinating"), you cannot play tunes with any instrument; you will always improvise when playing a tonal instrument.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) Also, if you are stunned or confused, magical instruments (except the magic whistle and Bell of Opening[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)) behave like their non-magical counterparts and do not consume charges when used.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

| Instrument                                                          | Type   | Non-magical equivalent |
| ------------------------------------------------------------------- | ------ | ---------------------- |
| [tooled horn](/wiki/Tooled_horn "Tooled horn")                      | Tonal  | *(non-magical)*        |
| [wooden flute](/wiki/Wooden_flute "Wooden flute")                   | Tonal  | *(non-magical)*        |
| [wooden harp](/wiki/Wooden_harp "Wooden harp")                      | Tonal  | *(non-magical)*        |
| [bugle](/wiki/Bugle "Bugle")                                        | Tonal  | *(non-magical)*        |
| [frost horn](/wiki/Frost_horn "Frost horn")                         | Tonal  | tooled horn            |
| [fire horn](/wiki/Fire_horn "Fire horn")                            | Tonal  | tooled horn            |
| [magic flute](/wiki/Magic_flute "Magic flute")                      | Tonal  | wooden flute           |
| [magic harp](/wiki/Magic_harp "Magic harp")                         | Tonal  | wooden harp            |
| [bell](/wiki/Bell "Bell")                                           | Atonal | *(non-magical)*        |
| [leather drum](/wiki/Leather_drum "Leather drum")                   | Atonal | *(non-magical)*        |
| [tin whistle](/wiki/Tin_whistle "Tin whistle")                      | Atonal | *(non-magical)*        |
| [Bell of Opening](/wiki/Bell_of_Opening "Bell of Opening")          | Atonal | bell                   |
| [drum of earthquake](/wiki/Drum_of_earthquake "Drum of earthquake") | Atonal | leather drum           |
| [magic whistle](/wiki/Magic_whistle "Magic whistle")                | Atonal | tin whistle            |

A [horn of plenty](/wiki/Horn_of_plenty "Horn of plenty") is not an instrument at all, even though its unidentified appearance is that of a [horn](/wiki/Horn "Horn").

## Messages

- You start playing \<instrument>.

  You improvised with a tonal instrument, or played an atonal instrument. This message is usually followed by other instrument-specific messages or effects.

- You radiate an obnoxious droning sound.

  As above, but you were stunned.

- You feel a monotonous vibration.

  As above, but you were both stunned and deaf.

- You generate a raucous noise.

  As above, but you were confused.

- You feel a jarring vibration.

  As above, but you were both confused and deaf.

- You disseminate a kaleidoscopic display of floating butterflies.

  As above, but you were hallucinating. (You get this even if you're deaf.)

- What you perform is quite far from music...

  As above, but you were some combination of stunned, confused and hallucinating. (You get this even if you're deaf.)

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/music.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 700](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/music.c#L700)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 3681](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/apply.c#L3681): *Bells call `use_bell()`, not `do_play_instrument()` like other instruments.*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/music.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 481](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/music.c#L481)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.4. Click here for more information.](/images/3/37/Nh364-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.4. Click here for more information.")

**This page may need to be updated for the [current version](/wiki/Current_version "Current version") of *NetHack*.**

It may contain text specific to [NetHack 3.6.4](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.4 "NetHack 3.6.4"). Information on this page may be out of date.

**Editors:** After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-364}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
html:
Musical instrument

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
This page is a stub. Should you wish to do so, you can contribute by expanding this page.

Musical instruments are tools that can be applied to produce music, causing some sort of effect. Instruments in NetHack fall into two categories: tonal instruments, which can play tunes (including the passtune), and atonal instruments, which cannot.

Some instruments are magical—they have effects beyond what their ordinary equivalent would yield. When they are uncharged, they behave identically to that equivalent. Every non-magical musical instrument except the bugle has at least one magical counterpart. Elven Priests and Wizards start with a non-magical musical instrument, excluding the tin whistle.

If you are stunned, confused, or hallucinating, you cannot play tunes with any instrument; you will always improvise when playing a tonal instrument.[1] Also, if you are stunned or confused, magical instruments (except the magic whistle and Bell of Opening[2]) behave like their non-magical counterparts and do not consume charges when used.[3]

Instrument Type Non-magical equivalent
tooled horn Tonal (non-magical)
wooden flute Tonal (non-magical)
wooden harp Tonal (non-magical)
bugle Tonal (non-magical)
frost horn Tonal tooled horn
fire horn Tonal tooled horn
magic flute Tonal wooden flute
magic harp Tonal wooden harp
bell Atonal (non-magical)
leather drum Atonal (non-magical)
tin whistle Atonal (non-magical)
Bell of Opening Atonal bell
drum of earthquake Atonal leather drum
magic whistle Atonal tin whistle

A horn of plenty is not an instrument at all, even though its unidentified appearance is that of a horn.

Messages

You start playing <instrument>.
You improvised with a tonal instrument, or played an atonal instrument. This message is usually followed by other instrument-specific messages or effects.
You radiate an obnoxious droning sound.
As above, but you were stunned.
You feel a monotonous vibration.
As above, but you were both stunned and deaf.
You generate a raucous noise.
As above, but you were confused.
You feel a jarring vibration.
As above, but you were both confused and deaf.
You disseminate a kaleidoscopic display of floating butterflies.
As above, but you were hallucinating. (You get this even if you're deaf.)
What you perform is quite far from music...
As above, but you were some combination of stunned, confused and hallucinating. (You get this even if you're deaf.)

References

  1. ↑ src/music.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 700
  2. ↑ src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 3681: Bells call use_bell(), not do_play_instrument() like other instruments.
  3. ↑ src/music.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 481

This page may need to be updated for the current version of NetHack.

It may contain text specific to NetHack 3.6.4. Information on this page may be out of date.

Editors: After reviewing this page and making necessary edits, please change the {{nethack-364}} tag to the current version's tag or {{noversion}} as appropriate.
